0.user_question: The number of students in a school hall was 2780965. The hall had 3 entrances A, B, and C which also served as the exits. If after a meeting 30% of the students went out of the building through exit A, 3/5 of the remaining went out through exit B, and the rest went out through exit C, calculate the number of students who went out through exit C.

direct_answer.text: Firstly let us find out how many students came into the school hall initially using all three (A,B & C) entry points. We know it’s only one entrance point so we can assume everyone comes in equally divided among these three. Therefore if you divide the initial student population by three parts; `3 /  3= 1` part per doorway means every single person entered via either of them hence meaning that no matter what path took place ,each would still equal half this value or `(half)*(initial_total)`. To put another way imagine taking away everything except those going down Exit A thus leaving behind just those not accounted for yet . Subtracting their count leaves exactly same amount counted already since our entire group size never changed ! Hence counting together both groups yields : `[remaining]+[ExitA] = original`. This forms basis upon whence following simple steps leading towards desired solution ; [remaining]=original-(EntryC+exitA)=TotalStudents -( TotalEntrances+(ExitEntries)/Each ) Since Number Entrance Count Entries Per Doorways Always Zero Thus Simplifies Further As Equivalent Of Original Given

0.user_question: The number of students in a school hall was 2780965. The hall had 3 entrances A, B, and C which also served as the exits. If after a meeting 30% of the students went out of the building through exit A, 3/5 of the remaining went out through exit B, and the rest went out through exit C, calculate the number of students who went out through exit C.

direct_answer.text: Firstly let us find out how many students came into the school hall initially using all three (A,B & C) entry points. We know it’s only one entrance point so we can assume everyone comes in equally divided among these three. Therefore if you divide the initial student population by three parts; `3 /  3= 1` part per doorway means every single person entered via either of them hence meaning that no matter what path took place ,each would still equal half this value or `(half)*(initial_total)`. To put another way imagine taking away everything except those going down Exit A thus leaving behind just those not accounted for yet . Subtracting their count leaves exactly same amount counted already since our entire group size never changed ! Hence counting together both groups yields : `[remaining]+[ExitA] = original`. This forms basis upon whence following simple steps leading towards desired solution ; [remaining]=original-(EntryC+exitA)=TotalStudents -( TotalEntrances+(ExitEntries)/Each ) Since Number Entrance Count Entries Per Doorways Always Zero Thus Simplifies Further As Equivalent Of Original Given
